qas.question: Ending with what century did religion play a smaller part in the curriculum of universities?
what model of university structure was being used throughout the world at the finish of the 19th century?
What was the focus of universities in the 20th century?

answers.text: chairman of the University Grants Committee

qas.question: What university did Sir Samuel Curran contribute to the creation of?
Ending with what century did German play a smaller part in the curriculum of universities?
What model of university structure was being used throughout the world at the finish of the 20th century?
What were the focus of grants in the 19th century?
Who formed a university in Germany?
What became less accessible to the masses?

context: Until the <a0_0>19th<a0_0/> century, religion played a significant role in university curriculum; however, the role of religion in research universities decreased in the 19th century, and by the end of the <b5_0>19th<b5_0/> century, <a1_0><b6_0>the German university model<b6_0/><a1_0/> had spread around the world. <b9_0>Universities<b9_0/> concentrated on <a2_0><b7_0>science<b7_0/><a2_0/> in the 19th and 20th centuries and became increasingly accessible to the masses. In Britain, the move from Industrial Revolution to modernity saw the arrival of new civic universities with an emphasis on science and engineering, a movement initiated in 1960 by Sir Keith Murray (<a3_0>chairman of the University Grants Committee<a3_0/>) and <b8_0>Sir Samuel Curran<b8_0/>, with the formation of <a4_0>the University of Strathclyde<a4_0/>. The British also established universities worldwide, and higher education became available to the masses not only in Europe.
